settings.title: For The Monochrome Lover
settings.desc:
The Expert: Makeup Artist Kate Synnott

The Look: A blush-tinged eye- and-lip combo is simple, yet impactful. "I wanted this look to be fresh and youthful while still having a little color pop," says Kate. She shares a step-by-step tutorial here. 

Try: Rose Inc Must-Have Makeup Set

settings.title: Apply the blush to the apples of the cheek
settings.desc: Blush placement can affect the overall look of your makeup. Generally, blush goes on the apples of the cheek. For blush newbies, Espinoza recommends spending time in front of the mirror familiarizing yourself with your face to better understand where to place blush. Pro tip: Smiling naturally lifts the apples of the cheek so they’re easier to locate. Furthermore, Milan says placing a bit of blush up toward the hairline helps lift the cheekbone, while  blending it lightly up into the temple creates more of an editorial look.

settings.quotes: "So many people have complimented these little accent lashes."

settings.title: For The Eyelash Enthusiast
settings.desc:
The Expert: Makeup Artist Priscilla Ono

The Look: Overstated lashes need not require a complicated protocol. “So many people have complimented these little accent lashes,” Priscilla says. “It's cool, different and easy to do.” See the full tutorial here.

Try: Holiday Color Favorites

settings.title: ICYMI: Everyday Fall Makeup with Anete Salinieka
settings.text_center:
Equal parts elegant and experimental, Anete proves in this tutorial that everyday makeup can be just as eye-catching. See the full story here.

Try: Eye Collection Set

settings.title: Apply blush between highlight and bronzer
settings.text_center: To help make blush application easier, Milan suggests thinking of cheek makeup as Neapolitan ice cream, which includes stacked layers ofvanilla, strawberry and chocolate. The highlight goes at the top of the cheekbone (vanilla). Blush goes in the middle on the apples of the cheeks (strawberry), and bronzer (chocolate) is placed below the cheekbone to contour. As for the order in which to apply them, Espinoza likes working from light to dark. Apply your highlight first, then blush and finallybronzer to contour and sculpt the face.

settings.title: Don't be afraid to mix blushes
settings.text_center: Ready to step your blush game up a notch? Espinoza recommends experimenting with different layers of blush colors and finishes to change up your look. "That is where I say the fun begins because that is where you become your own makeup artist, and you get to decide," he says. For instance, you can rock a cream blush during the day and then layer a liquid blush with some sparkle for a night out.
